description: From New Latin suppositius, from Latin suppositīcius.

adjectives.description: suppositious (comparative more suppositious, superlative most suppositious)

entries.meaning: Spurious; substituted for the genuine, counterfeit; fake; supposititious. [from 17th c.]
examples: […]  who knowes not how false, how suppositious, the writings and Epistles of the auncient Popes are iustly esteemed?

entries.meaning: Imaginary; fictitious, pretended to exist. [from 17th c.]
examples: At rehearsals the actor tossed an entirely imaginary cloak about his shoulders as though it were heavy brocade, courteously removed a hat made of air, and seriously set out on a suppositious table a non-existent dinner, after sedulously cooking it on a kitchen range that was a chair.

entries.meaning: Hypothetical, based on supposition; suppositional. [from 17th c.]
examples: Look, Dr. Lanning, let me present you with a suppositious case. Supposing we had a politician who was interested in defeating a reform candidate at any cost and while investigating his private life came across oddities such as I have just mentioned.
